Comments_List: I definitely gained an idea of how the immune system works, and how many different pieces there are. I also got a historical perspective on different epidemics such as polio, HIV/AIDS, and influenza which I'd never had before. Overall, although there's still so much to learn, I got a good introduction to immunology.

I learned about the remarkable capabilities of the human immune system and the microbiome. We reached precise details but also looked at the big picture, in the context of disease and history and the future. I realized the purpose of science and how beautiful and crucial its role is in our lives.

This course helped me develop a superficial understanding of scientific research along with an more in depth understanding of the bodies immunological functions. I learned about pathogens, innate and adaptive immunity, different viral diseases, tolerance, and some other topics.

In this course, I was introduced to immunology by learning the basic functions of the immune system and how different viruses and bacteria affect the human body. We discussed the scientific mechanisms, as well as the social ramifications, of various diseases and viruses.

In addition to covering fundamental information about the immune system, this class provided insight into growing fields of biology, such as the human microbiome and cancer immunotherapy. The class discussions also really helped me develop my points of view and expanded my knowledge on many of the subjects we learned and read about.

I learned all about the immune system and diseases in the context of hundreds of years. The course was a mixture of lectures and seminars, with Professor Kavathas providing both biological information and a space where intellectual discussion could occur.

I learned high level details about the human immune system and various different epidemics through history.  I also learned the specifics about vaccine development and various diseases (including polio, smallpox, influenza, HIV/AIDS).

This course was extremely interesting, engaging and informative. The layout of the course with part discussion and part lecture helped tie the social and molecular aspects of medicine and the immune system together. The course made me more sure that I want to pursue a career in medicine.

I learned about the Immune system, including the lymphatic system, innate and adaptive immunity, T-cells and B-cells, the history of Polio, antibodies, HIV, and autoimmune diseases. This class was absolutely amazing and I have learned about microbes and the roles they play in everyday life.
This course was amazing. It helped me develop both reading and interpretation skills.
I learned about both the biology and the social impacts of immunology.
Taking this course was a great introduction to seminars at Yale. I developed a good understanding of the basics of microbes and immunology.

By taking this course, I learned about the different parts of the immune system and how each part functions with each other. I also learned about different diseases and how the microbes that cause the diseases impair the immune system in one way or another. Not only did I learn about how the immune system and certain diseases worked, the class also taught me the history involved with the diseases and treatments that have been previously used and are now being used today.

I liked the readings we had and then the discussions we had on them; they were always interesting and engaging. The trips we took to the art museum and medical school were also amazing, interesting, and very fun. I thought the lectures were interesting, but sometimes we went through them too fast, so I didn't really understand. Maybe giving us time to take notes and going more slowly would help me retain more of the material.
Some concepts were a little hard to grasp conceptually. The lectures moved at a pretty fast pace.

The strength of this class with the instructor. She is a wonderful woman who welcomed us into her home and an even more inspiring instructor who is passionate about the work she does. She taught us in a manner that was engaging, informative and accessible. We learned through multiple mediums and really gained a full perspective on the immune system and the microbiome.

A strength of this course was that it provided me with a lot of information. Also, the course allowed students to discuss information in class. A weakness of the course is that the information could have been presented a little better.

I loved this course. It was structured very well, with class time split between lecture and open-ended discussions. A big strength was the small size of the class that allowed for lively discussion and culminated in a tight-knit group of peers.

strengths: intellectually challenging; manageable workload; relevant, relatable readings; taught in an engaging way; good balance between lectures, class discussions, and hands-on activities 
weaknesses: none

The strength of this course is Professor Kavathas who really paid attention to every student and ensured that they understood the immune system. I really enjoyed how this course not only used concepts from Molecular Biology but History of Science as well. I did not find any weaknesses of this course.

The course was informative and engaging. The discussions were very collaborative and Professor Kavathas had activities that helped with the learning process and engaged the class more. Some of the readings however were excessively long and tedious.
The strengths of the course include the insightful discussions we had over books and articles relevant to the immune system and other diseases, along with the brilliant professor.
The professor was amazing and this course was well taught.
The professor is very passionate and very understanding.

The strengths of this class were the balance of lectures and discussions. The problem sets were helpful to learn the material and the final paper allowed the class to explore specific infections and diseases more in-depth.

One strength of the course is the organization. Another strength is the obvious joy you can see on Professor Kavathas's face when she teaches because she truly loves the subject matter. One weakness of the course is the fact that some readings are very long and dull. Another weakness is that the class size was big for a seminar, so sometimes it was hard to voice your opinion in discussion. The course can be improved by cutting the irrelevant sections in longer readings and cutting down the class size.

Yes I would, I thought the professor was great and she really tried to make the class engaging for the students. The split format between discussion and lecture was also good, and we got to learn about very interesting things. Although some of the lecture material went too fast and was confusing, overall I really enjoyed this class and would recommend it.
I would recommend this course to students who are interested in biology or immunology, as well as the history of various diseases.
Yes, I definitely would! You do not have to be science major to take this course, and the topics and instructor are really interesting and engaging.
I would recommend this course to another student if they wanted to major in a STEM area.
Absolutely! Even if you aren't sure you want to go into MCDB or even the sciences, this class will encourage you to see the immune system in a different way.

Yes I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The course is very intellectually rich while simultaneously having a very manageable workload. This course is suitable for both STEM and non-STEM students.

Yes! This course was simply wonderful! I believe this really gives an insight for the concepts that will be learned in either Molecular Biology or History of Science and is a great course to have fun talking about science and its infrastructure.

Yes, I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in biology and the human immune system. I would also recommend this class to those who are interested in science, but want to approach the subject from a more historical side.
Yes I would recommend the course to another student. Professor Kavathas is a great teacher!
This course is essential for grasping a foundation about the immune system and how it works. The teacher is amazing and you will definitely have a great time learning.
Yes it was amazing.
Yes, this course is a great intro.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. If you're even slightly interested in the immune system, this course is for you. The readings are engaging, the lectures are interesting, and the discussions always make you think about medicine in our world. Professor Kavathas is an absolute delight in class. Although the class is a little fast-paced at times, Professor Kavathas is kind enough to make a booklet that summarizes the lectures for review.
